passage:
(1) Marie Curie, born Maria Skłodowska in 1867 in Warsaw, Poland, stands as one of the most influential scientists in history, whose groundbreaking work fundamentally altered our understanding of atomic structure and radioactivity. After facing gender discrimination in her homeland, she moved to Paris where she pursued higher education at the Sorbonne, displaying remarkable dedication despite financial hardships and demanding study conditions. Her perseverance ultimately led to her becoming the first woman to receive a doctorate in physics in France, an achievement that foreshadowed her future scientific contributions and her role in breaking gender barriers in academia.

(2) Curie's most significant scientific breakthrough came through her collaborative research with her husband, Pierre Curie, when they discovered two new elements: polonium, named after her native Poland, and radium. Working in primitive laboratory conditions, the couple processed tons of pitchblende ore to isolate minute amounts of these radioactive elements, demonstrating extraordinary commitment to scientific inquiry. Their meticulous work led to the development of the theory of radioactivity, which explained how certain elements spontaneously emit energy in the form of radiation, a discovery that fundamentally changed physics and chemistry and opened the door to understanding atomic structure.

(3) Beyond her theoretical contributions, Marie Curie recognized the practical applications of her discoveries, particularly in medicine. During World War I, she developed mobile X-ray units that could be transported to the battlefield, allowing doctors to locate bullets and shrapnel in wounded soldiers. She personally drove these 'radiological cars' to the front lines and trained women as operators, saving countless lives and establishing the field of radiology. This practical application of scientific knowledge demonstrated her commitment to using science for humanitarian purposes, a principle that continues to inspire researchers today.

(4) Despite her extraordinary accomplishments, Curie faced persistent gender bias throughout her career. When she became the first person to receive two Nobel Prizes – in Physics (1903) and Chemistry (1911) – many scientific institutions remained reluctant to fully acknowledge her contributions. The French Academy of Sciences refused to elect her as a member, and she faced scandalous press coverage about her personal life. Nevertheless, she maintained her dignity and focus on scientific work, establishing a powerful precedent for women in science and eventually founding the Curie Institutes in Paris and Warsaw, which remain prominent research centers.

(5) Tragically, Marie Curie's pioneering work with radioactive materials ultimately contributed to her death from aplastic anemia in 1934, likely caused by her prolonged exposure to radiation at a time when its dangers were not fully understood. Her scientific notebooks remain so radioactive that they must be stored in lead-lined boxes, and researchers must wear protective gear to examine them. This poignant detail underscores both the revolutionary nature of her work and its personal cost. Marie Curie's legacy extends beyond her scientific discoveries to her role as a trailblazer for women in science, her ethical approach to research, and her belief that knowledge should benefit humanity – principles that continue to guide scientific endeavors in the twenty-first century.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of the correct use of the present perfect continuous tense?

options.A: She will have been working on that project for three years by next June.
options.B: I was working on my thesis when you called.
options.C: He has been studying French since he moved to Paris.
options.D: They worked on the solution for several hours yesterday.

questions.question: Identify the sentence with the correct conditional form.

options.A: If I would have known about the meeting, I would have attended it.
options.B: If she hadn't missed her flight, she would have arrived on time.
options.C: If we will finish early, we can go to the concert.
options.D: Unless you would help me, I cannot complete this task.

questions.question: Which sentence demonstrates the correct use of a participle clause?

options.A: Having finished his work, he decided to go for a walk.
options.B: After he had finished his work, he decided to go for a walk.
options.C: He finished his work and then decided to go for a walk.
options.D: When his work was finished, he decided to go for a walk.

questions.question: Choose the sentence with the correct use of reported speech.

options.A: She said that she will attend the conference tomorrow.
options.B: He told me that he has completed the assignment already.
options.C: They said that they were planning to visit us the following day.
options.D: The professor announced that the exam will be the most difficult.

questions.question: Identify the sentence with the correct use of articles.

options.A: The professor is giving a lecture on a evolution of human species.
options.B: We had the dinner at the new Italian restaurant on Main Street.
options.C: She plays the violin in an orchestra based in the Netherlands.
options.D: He has a MBA from a prestigious university in United States.

questions.question: Which sentence contains a grammatically correct use of inversion?

options.A: Rarely I have seen such a magnificent performance.
options.B: Hardly had we arrived when it started to rain heavily.
options.C: Not only she speaks French, but also German and Italian.
options.D: Under no circumstances we should reveal this information.

questions.question: Choose the correct relative clause structure.

options.A: The book which I borrowed it from the library is very interesting.
options.B: The woman who house was damaged in the storm has filed an insurance claim.
options.C: The city in which we spent our vacation was stunningly beautiful.
options.D: The man whom car broke down called for assistance.

questions.question: Identify the sentence with correct subject-verb agreement.

options.A: The committee have decided to postpone the meeting.
options.B: Neither the students nor the teacher were able to solve the problem.
options.C: A number of issues has been raised during the discussion.
options.D: The data suggests that our hypothesis is correct.

questions.question: Which sentence demonstrates the correct use of a gerund?

options.A: To swimmming in cold water is invigorating.
options.B: She enjoys to reading historical novels in her spare time.
options.C: Despite to try several times, he couldn't passing the exam.
options.D: Swimming in cold water is invigorating.

questions.question: Choose the sentence with the correct use of passive voice.

options.A: The experiment will conducted by the research team next month.
options.B: A new approach has been developed to address this issue.
options.C: The building was build in the 19th century.
options.D: The criminal was arresting by the police last night.

questions.question: Identify the sentence with the correct use of modals for deduction.

options.A: He must to have missed the train, as he's not here yet.
options.B: She can't be at home; I just saw her at the supermarket.
options.C: They might went to the cinema after dinner.
options.D: You should have been more careful, then this wouldn't happen.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the future perfect tense correctly?

options.A: By this time next year, I will graduate from university.
options.B: She will be working on her thesis for three months by June.
options.C: They will have completed the project before the deadline.
options.D: We will living in this city for ten years next month.

questions.question: Choose the sentence with correct parallel structure.

options.A: The CEO likes hiking, swimming, and to ride bicycles.
options.B: She not only excels in mathematics but also in physics.
options.C: The job requires a person who is efficient, creative, and has organizational skills.
options.D: The professor emphasized the importance of critical thinking, thorough research, and clear writing.

questions.question: Identify the sentence with correct punctuation.

options.A: Despite the heavy rain they decided to go ahead with the outdoor event.
options.B: The conference which was scheduled for next week has been postponed.
options.C: After considering all options, the committee made its final decision; the proposal was rejected.
options.D: Although he studied diligently, he didn't pass the exam, because he misunderstood the key concepts.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the subjunctive mood correctly?

options.A: I wish I was able to attend the ceremony last week.
options.B: It is essential that he is present at the meeting tomorrow.
options.C: The teacher insisted that the student completes the assignment by Friday.
options.D: The committee recommended that the proposal be accepted without further changes.

questions.question: Choose the most suitable phrasal verb meaning 'to meet someone halfway or accept a less than ideal compromise': 'During the protracted negotiations, both parties had to _____ some of their initial demands to reach a consensus.'
Select the correct idiomatic expression to complete the sentence: 'The new employee is very enthusiastic but lacks experience; he'll have to ________ before taking on major responsibilities.'
Identify the correct collocation in the following sentence: 'The researcher needs to ________ further experiments to validate the initial findings.'
Choose the correct preposition to complete the sentence: 'Her research findings differ significantly ________ those of her colleagues.'
Select the appropriate linking word to complete the sentence: 'The experiment proved successful; ________, it opened up new avenues for research.'
Identify the sentence with the correct use of a fixed expression:

options.A: The company is in red numbers after the economic downturn.
options.B: She's been working around the watch to complete the project.
options.C: You need to take this opportunity with both hands.
options.D: All things considered, the project was a significant success.

questions.question: Choose the most appropriate formal alternative to the underlined phrase: 'The manager didn't like the report and told us to do it again.'

options.A: The manager disapproved of the report and instructed us to revise it.
options.B: The manager hated the report and ordered us to redo it.
options.C: The manager wasn't into the report and said we should try once more.
options.D: The manager got upset with the report and wanted a new version.

questions.question: Select the most appropriate register for an academic paper: 'Research has shown that...'

options.D: Most of the public think that...

questions.question: Identify the correct word form to complete the sentence: 'The ________ of new technology has transformed the way we communicate.'
Choose the correct multi-word verb to complete the sentence: 'We need to ________ the problem before making any decisions.'
The professor's ________ approach to teaching engaged even the most disinterested students, making complex concepts accessible through real-world examples.
The company's ________ spending habits allowed it to weather the economic downturn without resorting to layoffs or budget cuts.
The student's ________ comments during the serious academic discussion made the professor question his commitment to the course.
The journalist's exposé revealed the ________ conditions in which factory workers were forced to operate, with hazardous materials and no protective equipment.
There was an ________ understanding among team members that all decisions would be made collectively, though this was never formally stated in any document.
The critic praised the author's ________ in addressing controversial topics with honesty and straightforwardness rather than resorting to euphemisms.
The philanthropist's ________ was evident in his substantial donations to educational institutions and community development programs.
Access to clean water has been a ________ to the remote village, dramatically improving health outcomes and quality of life for its residents.
Some bacteria can have a ________ effect on human health, causing severe diseases that are resistant to traditional antibiotics.
The supervisor did not hesitate to ________ the employee for repeatedly failing to meet deadlines, making it clear that such behavior was unacceptable.
Despite living in a cosmopolitan city for years, her ________ attitudes remained unchanged, as she continued to view urban customs with suspicion and favor the traditions of her small hometown.
The negotiations took a ________ route, with multiple detours and unexpected obstacles before finally reaching a conclusion that satisfied all parties.
The teacher had to ________ the students for their behavior during the field trip, explaining firmly but calmly why their actions were inappropriate.
The protesters claimed that the new industrial plant would ________ the natural beauty of the landscape and contaminate the surrounding ecosystem.
His ________ behavior at the formal dinner, including inappropriate jokes and excessive drinking, embarrassed his colleagues and damaged professional relationships.
According to paragraph 1, Marie Curie faced what challenge before moving to Paris?
The word 'meticulous' in paragraph 2 is closest in meaning to:
What practical application of her scientific discoveries did Marie Curie develop during World War I?

options.C: Mobile X-ray units for battlefield use

questions.question: According to the passage, what was unusual about Marie Curie's Nobel Prize achievements?

options.A: She won in both Physics and Chemistry
options.B: She was the youngest recipient at that time
options.C: She was the first person to receive two Nobel Prizes
options.D: She was the first person who shared both prizes with her husband

questions.question: The word 'poignant' in paragraph 5 most nearly means:
What can be inferred about Marie Curie's personal values from the passage?

options.A: She valued personal recognition above scientific progress.
options.B: She believed scientific knowledge should benefit humanity.
options.C: She prioritized theoretical work over practical applications.
options.D: She focused exclusively on advancing women's rights in science.

questions.question: Why are Marie Curie's notebooks stored in lead-lined boxes?

options.A: To preserve them from environmental damage
options.B: To prevent theft of valuable historical artifacts
options.C: Because they contain dangerous chemical formulas

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the organization of the passage?

options.A: Chronological order of Marie Curie's life events
options.B: Comparison between Marie Curie and other scientists of her time
options.C: Analysis of different aspects of Marie Curie's contributions and challenges
options.D: Description of the scientific principles behind Marie Curie's discoveries

questions.question: Which statement best captures the main idea of paragraph 4?

options.A: Marie Curie faced significant gender bias despite her extraordinary achievements.
options.B: The French Academy of Sciences was reluctant to admit women members.
options.C: Marie Curie's personal life became the subject of scandalous press coverage.
options.D: Marie Curie established research institutes that continue her legacy.

questions.question: Based on the passage, Marie Curie's legacy includes all of the following EXCEPT:

options.A: Her role as a pioneer for women in science
options.B: Her ethical approach to scientific research
options.C: Her commercial patents for radioactive materials
options.D: Her humanitarian application of scientific discoveries
